Personally, I don't think members of Congress should profit from wars they send other people to fight.
Today, let us all honor the brave women fighting back against corporate exploitation, imperialism, and economic oppression across the globe.

In both 2021 and 2022, thousands of women took to the picket lines in the US to stand up to corporate greed and demand better pay and dignified working conditions. And right now, thousands of Russian women are filling the streets of their cities to protest Putin’s war in Ukraine.

Since then, courageous women activists have used the day to protest wars in Spain (1937), Italy (1943), and across Europe (2003).

Thus this year’s celebration takes on special meaning.

Perhaps the most significant anti-war protest took place in 1917 in Petrograd—then the capital of Russia—when millions of women filled the streets to protest WWI and demand “bread & peace.” The action helped topple Russia’s czarist regime and won Russian women the right to vote.

On March 8, 1908, 15K working women in NYC mobilized for better pay, shorter working hours, and women’s suffrage—planting the seeds for what we now call International Women’s Day. Since its inception, IWD served as a focal point for both labor demonstrations and antiwar protests.
I'm on with @mehdirhasan tonight, should you wish to tune in. https://t.co/JHUtu7BUga

The Child Tax Credit expansion lifted millions of kids out of poverty.

Congress decided to let it expire.

Now over a third of families with children in the U.S. say they are struggling to cover ordinary costs.

When I say poverty is a policy choice, this is what I mean.
We shouldn't have to choose between fighting Putin and taking care of Americans. We can, and must, do both.

Biden's ban on Russian energy imports won’t be particularly impactful, but it will disproportionately impact low-income people already hurt by high gas prices. Congress must act to help Americans caught in this energy squeeze. Extending the Child Tax Credit would be a good start.

One answer: U.S. laws on taxes, corporations, transportation, and banking are wonderfully convenient for the wealthy. We make it easy for them to stash their assets in complex trusts and shell companies.

The new cold war is underway. The biggest difference between the old cold war and the new one is this: one of the major political parties in the U.S. is marching towards outright authoritarianism and doesn’t show any signs of slowing down.

US employers added 678,000 jobs in February—well beyond predictions. While this is good news, wages didn’t grow at all.

Average hourly earnings went up just one cent, but the Fed is still set to raise interest rates later this month to head off a nonexistent “wage-price spiral."
